Comment: At least 3 of the large fires in Oregon (Whitewater, Chetco, Jones) are re-burning large areas that were first burned 15-20 years ago.  That is part of the reason they are "large".  The re-burned areas are difficult for the fire fighting agencies to deal with because of safety issues and because they contain large amounts of standing and down "large" (logs larger then 24") that burn hotter and longer than fires in other areas.   In the fire lingo, they have high resistance to control.  The size of fires does not stand up to a cause and effect explanation of climate change.  Ms. Driscoll is probably familiar with the situation on the Jones fire, since the local environmental groups strongly opposed any salvage harvesting of the Clark Fire (in Fall Creek) which left tons of standing and down fuels over about 3,000 acres which the Jones fire is now "cleaning up".

Comment: The questions contain compounding options and thus have four possible meanings

E.g :  'do you think having breakfast is good for you, and is cereal good to eat at that time?' Yes or No?

('Even if' creates a similar set up)

Yes I think breakfast is good, no cereal isn't good for you 
No I don't think breakfast is good, but if you are going to eat then, cereal is good for you
Yes breakfast is good and yes cereal is good
No breakfast is not good and cereal is not good for you

Any response someone would give to that question would not be decipherable 

On the other hand it is the perfect questionnaire for the minister involved

Comment: There are several conflicting legal theories in this case.  The first is jurisdiction (which court has the authority to hear the case) and that will generally be settled by the two trial judges hearing the case but must comply with the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act.  Alaska had it to start with but may now have to share it with Texas.  Then there is ICWA which as to custody of Native children, pre-empts State law.  Native relatives have the preference.  Finally, there is the presumption against granting a domestic violence perpetrator custody.  I doubt that dad will ever have custody or visitation with these kids but that is not guaranteed.  If they are settled in Texas, let them stay there - it's their best interests which should be the deciding factor and not legal gamesmanship.

Comment: I strongly DISAGREE with Darryl Perry's opinion here.  

Perry's first main point is that Medical Marijuana patients are abusing "legal loopholes."  First, he affirms that he recognizes the medicinal benefits of cannabis - for those with serious debilitating medical conditions - but immediately goes on to suggest that the overwhelming majority of medical marijuana patients ("95%") are... what exactly?  Faking it?  Abusing a law not designed to address the health benefits of cannabis?  Exploring areas of the law that are silent in order to seek out medical relief?   

In that same vein, Perry talks about the risk being placed on the general public by medical marijuana patients.  Where's the data for this risk?  How does this risk stack up against legal alcohol consumption?  I hope Perry is as adamant in his opposition of recreational alcohol consumption as he is in his efforts to stifle cannabis use. 

Perry, is it a mistake to criminalize the homeless?  Thoughts on rail?

Comment: Most,  if not all, of PERS problems were self inflicted wounds by the PERS Board in good investment return years,  where ALL of the gains over the 8% goal were given that year to those on the PERS system.  Not a penny was reserved for down years for investment returns.  The Obama foot on the neck of the Fed to keep interest low so he could deficit spend with minimal interest punished any and all who were saving or invested in their retirements.  Only PERS has a minimum annual return guarantee,  and zero obligation to leave any returned over the minimum in the reserves:  Public employees get the gains,  and the taxpayers get the underages to make up.  I don't think that is a contract,  because a contract has to treat each party with parity.  I don't think taxpayers are fairly represented in that scenario.  Unintended consequences,  windfall gains,  and losses infilled by the taxpayers.  The only answer I can see is to pare the size of government,  payouts to persons and entities.

Comment: Jean Chrétien after the 1995 referendum initiated a reference to the Supreme Court about the legality of a unilateral declaration of independence from a Canadian province.  In the SC opinion neither Canadian law nor international law allow Quebec to secede unilaterally. It confirmed that international law "does not specifically grant component parts of sovereign states the legal right to secede unilaterally from their 'parent' state.".  It stated in its opinion that under international law, the right to secede unilaterally was meant for peoples under a colonial rule or foreign occupation.

The SC stated that the rest of Canada "would have no basis to deny the right of the government of Quebec to pursue secession" should the results in a referendum come in favour of independence; and negotiations would have to follow to define the terms under which Quebec would gain independence.

Agreed, the decision of the Supreme Court of Canada is viewed by all as a model.

Comment: Just to correct a factual error: the US no longer has 10 times the population of Canada (which those of us who are old enough remember it being for decades). Due to differences in growth, largely related to immigration, the US only has 9 times the population (316.5 M vs. 35.16 M as of 2013, 322.8 M vs. 36.3 M as of 2016, dropping from 9x to 8.9x over 3 years), and under the current US administration that difference in growth is only likely to accelerate. Given the factors that other commentators here have mentioned, and the new EU deal (EU-28 pop. 510.1 M in 2016), while Canada may not have blunt leverage as the article suggests, our vulnerability in a trade war with the US is diminishing over time. The Liberal gov't should be hedging their bets that way even as they avoid poking the US admin. in the eye.

Comment: It's true, plants have defense mechanisms set up for protection from threats.  Not all those "pesticides" you are referring to are what you make them out to be. Sometimes the plant will send out a scent to attract beneficial insects.

I agree that there are some plant produced chemicals that are detrimental to human health like  Alkaloids found in Nightshades.

Phenolic compounds like resveratrol, flavonoids, and furanocoumarins have been shown to be beneficial, others can have toxic effects. Not enough research to draw anything conclusive on the effects they have on human health. More research is needed.

Plants don't just have all these chemicals in every cell of the plant, often you will find higher concentrations in different parts of the plant like in the specific part of the plant that is under "attack" or in the roots (fungal protection) or the leaves, the stalks etc...

I feel your comment is misleading and does not explain the whole story. To me it is a fear mongering tactic

Comment: Canada needs to treat residential real estate as a critical resource for citizens.

Frankly, we need limit residential real estate ownership to citizens of this country.  That is the only way to keep housing affordable for Canadians.  Housing has a drastic effect on our cost of living and standard of living in this country.  Why Canada has continued to allow our housing to be treated as a commodity on the global market is crazy.

A lot of countries around the world have realized that there is only so much land that can be used for housing without having to sacrifice prime agricultural land.  As such, they have put restrictions on property ownership.

We need to put in restrictions before it is too late.  (although it might be too late for some cities, Vancouver? Toronto?)

The secondary benefit of restricting property ownership?  It adds value to Canadian citizenship.

Foreign students, workers need housing?  That can be accommodated through the rental market.

Comment: I hear TRC Solutions is doing the water testing.

With the EPA procedure:
Running the water first, waiting 6-8 hours, and then taking a sample is not a good way to test. It is not representative of even the time between Monday afternoon to Tuesday morning, let alone during a summer break.

Example:
Someone runs a fountain, waits 8 hours, and gets a reading of 5 ppb.
If the fountain is used at 4 pm Friday, then by Monday morning at 8 am (64 hours later), the amount of lead coming out could be 5 ppb x 8 = 40 ppb (above the limit).  

Please consider letting the water be stagnant for longer than 6-8 hours before testing.

Also, what is being done about stagnant water after long breaks?

Comment: It's hard to be objective, as a survivor of childhood abuse from a 14 y.o. boy when I was 9.  I read with some interest why teenage sex offenders who get treatment are at a much lower risk of re-offense - it is a relief.  Looking back on my life in the decades since then, the sexual assault had and continues to have an impact on my life, so I cannot minimize the impact on the victim in this case.  Do I feel a poor choice at 15 should prevent a young man from playing the sport (on the road to being professional) in which he excels? Maybe - not as a punishment, but as a deterrent and a pressure to change our culture.  In my case, and I'm sure this isn't unique, teenage boys seem to be excused for being "horny" when really they are exploiting vulnerable children. (Sexual attraction between similar aged teens is a totally different thing).  So, yes, if this is what is necessary to get ADULTS to take responsibility for teaching and monitoring the teens in their lives, then YES.

Comment: Mr. Lamoureux, perhaps the most important thing about your article (and your cooperation with Charles Wohlforth) is that it sounds like you really are being candid about the state of American health care.  My experience is that providers deliberately stay ignorant about costs--"You'll have to talk to billing"--and encourage patients not to consider it: "Don't worry, Medicare covers it and you have medi-gap coverage, too".  At "billing," they simply say it's not possible to tell you what something will cost: "We don't know what equipment they may need, or what complications might develop."  So, unlike any other economic transaction, the consumer incurs unknown financial responsibility for something he doesn't understand. I had a simple outpatient procedure done at Prov.  The bill was $35,000!  I was in the building less than 2 hours!  My insurance would pay $13,000 max.  I told the Prov billing office I simply wouldn't pay the rest.  "Oh, we write off a lot," she said airily.

Comment: It's unfortunate that the NJI refuses to reveal how it trains judges in sexual assault law. The public needs confidence that such training is fair and impartial to both complainant and the accused.

In defending the NJI's refusal, its executive director likened the training judges receive in sexual assault law to the kinds of influence they would be subject to by reading the news! Surely that's an invalid comparison. Society wants judges to be engaged and aware citizens. But specific training judges receive in this specific area of law is clearly intended to lead judges in their decisions in sexual assault trials. Or there would be no point to the training. 

The NJI hasn't acted in the public's interest in this matter. An alternative means of access to the materials should be used.

Comment: Except you assume the economic problems in Quebec stemmed from protectionism rather than paternalism and an over-reliance on an agrarian economy.  And then you assume that the only reason Quebec chose to stay in Canada was due to a weak economy.  

While Quebec's economy benefits from being part of Canada, a stronger economy would have been as much a reason to stay because most Quebec products are consumed within Canada.  If Quebec had voted to leave while the economy was robust, the Federal government would have had an excellent case for compensation and payment of Quebec's share of national debt. 

If anything, Quebec's weak economy at the time of the secessionist votes should have been the compelling factor to vote to leave Canada.  Indeed, it should have been sufficient proof that Canada's best economic interests weren't aligned with Quebecs best interests.  The failure of the vote to leave perhaps demonstrates there's more to life than simple economics.

Comment: Consider the example of feral rabbits in Australia: because some Scottish wanker wanted something to shoot at from his front porch, he released 25 rabbits.  The exploding population rendered huge tracts of interior Australia into moonscapes.  Many of them will probably never recover--they haven't in well over a century.

The ultimate result of the human-abetted proliferation of invasive felines may well prove to be mass extinction-induced ecological collapse and/or cat-vectored zoonotic disease pandemics.  Thanks to the misguided efforts of the "no-kill" imbeciles and TNR cat-hoarders, one-third of human rabies exposures in the US have been cat-vectored for the last 28 years (which, not-so-coincidentally, marked the advent of TNR in the US).

That's 13,000 exposures a year, each requiring PEP (post-exposure prophylactic) inoculation at from $3,000-$26,000/year.  The greatest incidence of human rabies exposure in US HISTORY--665 people--was caused by a TNR colony in Concord, NH in 1994.

Comment: Means testing will inflame the politics of jealousy. Example: I paid a lot of taxes all my life. I became ill, I couldn't work. The PharmaCare program looked at my preceding income & announced I didn't qualify for drug subsidy - despite having no income. 

How did that make me feel - knowing I had paid for years into a program that was for everyone except for those who paid into it?  The key to Canada's success in universal health care is its universality. Take that away & you alienate the very people needed to ensure continued funding. 

Easy to say, "Too bad, the successful will have to pay tax whether or not they can collect any benefits," but that is shortsighted. Once healed, I made a decision to not work as much, to not cross the next tax threshold, to collect every receipt and to ensure I minimised the tax I pay using every legal strategy. The government is down about $45,000 last year, all because they tried to cheat me. Currently it is left-wing policy to apply means tests.

Comment: There is both.  Men are more likely to work full-time which not only involves more hours but (on average) higher pay.  Men, on average, spend more years of their life working (the don't take as much time off for things like raising children and they retire later).  All of this contributes, as you note, to an "income gap".

However even adjusting for those two factors there is also a wage gap.  Why?  Well that comes down, at least in part, to the types of jobs that are more commonly held by men vs. the types of jobs more commonly held by women.  There are other factors though, like men are more persistent about demanding a raise from their employer.  Men likely also place a relatively higher importance on wages vs. non-wage benefits (things like health insurance) compared to women.

Lots of difference for lots of reasons, but it is unclear a.) IF the government SHOULD do anything and b.) what the government COULD do even if it wanted to.

Comment: Religious law is included in the definition of “legal system” in dictionaries. Canon law does not cease to be a legal system because there is something about it you don’t like. I don’t particularly like capital punishment, but those States which allow it do not cease to have legal systems as a result. Like civil law, canon law has sets of rules that provide minimum standards of conduct, the breach of which involves punishment. A clear distinction is drawn in both systems between moral obligations and legal ones. They both have means of promulgation, interpretation and enforcement through courts.  They have systems of study and conferring of degrees. There is no need to “ban” canon law where it requires disobedience to civil law, because civil law effectively does that. If canon law requires bishops to break the civil law, they will still be punished by the civil legal system if they do. Bishop Pican in France is a good example.

Comment: You make reasonable points, and yes, any one piece of evidence in isolation is inconclusive. If you look at reports on this specific subject by Crowdstrike, ThreatConnect and SecureWorks, you see that they are aggregating a lot of different pieces of evidence to get confidence in attribution. A couple of important points though:

First, avoiding attribution is very difficult for attackers to do, because there are so many ways to leak information. False flagging attacks like that, which is what we are talking about here, to emulate another hacker group with that much precision, without leaving a single clue about yourself, is probably impossible.

Second, intelligence agencies usually know for certain, and they figure it out by counter-attacking and monitoring these groups to the best of their ability from the inside. They are secretive about it, because that is the nature of espionage, but when they make positive statements that agree with outside analysis, doubt becomes difficult.

Comment: My comment about modern government surveillance techniques was a general one. No one can deny that government's today can and do use mass surveillance techniques on the public. And the government does everything it can to conceal those activities.

Within that greater surveillance regime we have the government employing secretive methods to investigate alleged crimes. But whereas the government can do almost anything it pleases with mass surveillance- because it doesn't need judicial review- it must reveal its methods in a criminal trial. If it doesn't, then the evidence can't be tested for its accuracy and legality. And evidence that can't be tested by council is virtually worthless in court.

Having a judge's approval to wire-tap a phone doesn't prove that all the evidence submitted was gathered lawfully. Each piece of evidence is subject to careful examination in court.

Comment: I agree: the majority are not over-leveraged. That has been true pretty consistently in every price run-up & correction for a long time.

I've looked a bit at past ups and downs in major Canadian real estate markets (esp. the Lower Mainland). What strikes me about now (vs. other times) is the duration+magnitude of this bull run relative to others (prices quadrupled in about 12 years in Vancouver), the record high multiples that some people owe relative to their earning potential, and the very high dependency of the wider economy on this one sector.

Re: the latter, I know multiple realtors in their 40s who owe relatively little on houses that have risen to incredible valuations. Price declines aren't his concern. Earning a pay cheque is. A record % of people work in this area. A vicious cycle is a big concern. 

The scale of the price changes in the last 10-15 years in some Canadian cities bear little resemblance to those of many preceding decades. This is not 91 in TO, 81 in YVR, etc.

Comment: Magnitsky Act is named after the late Russian Sergei Magnitsky. He was an accountant by profession and practice but has been often incorrectly identified in the West as a lawyer. 
His natural death from natural cause (pancreatitis ) was unfortunate indeed.  However, similar precedents occur in Canada yearly.  According to the Annual Report of the Office of the Correctional Investigator, between 2014-15, there were 43 deaths in CSC facilities attributed to “natural causes.” 36% of all natural cause deaths were deemed “unexpected” – the result of sudden cardiac arrest, complications arising from medical procedures or rapid disease progression. Hypothetically, death resulting from inadequate or non-existent medical care or due to negligence by the guards while in custody in Canadian prisons, if viewed through the lens of human rights abuse, can set a precedent for foreign jurisdictions: Canadian officials might be sued by a foreign country and their assets arrested under this cause.

Comment: The problem really isn't oil, its trains. A train carrying soybeans, cars, or lumber to the port blocks traffic just as long as one carrying oil.
We're stuck with the unintended consequences of decisions, made 40-odd years ago, that changed the land between East Wishkah and the river from industrial to retail. 
The Port of Grays Harbor has an obligation to the voters to grow its business, to attract customers. If it doesn't handle oil, it will handle something else. The cheapest way to move cargo to and from the port is by train. Take out the train tracks and the streets would, at best, be filled with trucks. At worst, the shippers would go elsewhere.
Being stranded in the mall parking lot may be an unavoidable cost. We’ve tolerated worse in the past.

Comment: Correct. The market exists at the current price entirely because of the overhead of running an illegal operation (which includes the threat of violence from one's competitors).  The new "legal" market will have to price the product at some point lower than this, or there will not be any legal sales. 

However, given that the product will now be legal, and given the ease with which it can be produced, the "legal" market will almost certainly be saturated with a product priced only marginally above the price of production, regardless of provincial government attempts to direct the public to particular stores.

Put another way: the government has an abysmal record enforcing regulation of this product already, but somehow thinks it can square the circle of legalizing it *and* restricting access to the product via its preferred sales channels. Not a chance.

Comment: Speaking of the middle class, a good friend a hard working Republican (with a good middle class job paying him $200,000 in his last years before retirement) did not realize that retiring at his age, he had to take a certain amount of money out of his 401K each year and pay ordinary income tax on it. He could not leave it in his account until he needed it and he had no way to stop the conversion of the capital gains in the 401K into ordinary income even though he earned them through risk and capital gain from careful investing. His brother on the other hand has been able to shelter money and convert a lot to capital gains though deferred participation in partnerships, and other devices available to him. So he and his brother took comparable risks, but the tax law favored his higher bracket brother much better. Until this hit him personally, he did not realize how big a deal this was and how much things were stacked against him even at his level.

Comment: TOTALLY agree. I didn't wanna jump on it that hard, as Kami's a Broncos fan & agreed w/your overall point. 
The stat about teams' success when their bell-cow, or entire team, has X amount of carries, is silly, & reverse engineering.
Of COURSE teams win % is going to be generally higher in games where they rush it more.
1. When we're ahead, we're going to rush the ball more to milk the clock. I'll bet there's a GINORMOUS correlation between 4th quarter carries & winning %.
MORE importantly, 
2. Continuing to run the ball when we're averaging 1.5 yards a carry is going to ensure that we're continually be PUNTING the ball. 
And on the FLIP side, 
3. If we're averaging 6 yards per carry we're gonna have a LOT fewer 3rd & longs, & are gonna keep running it, since it's a LOT safer than passing. Turnovers aside, it's virtually impossible to LOSE a game when successfully running it.
THAT'S why teams who've won have more carries. Not because they rushed it just to hit 20 carries.

Comment: Every initiative which is passed, just as every law passed by the legislature or ordinance passed by a local jurisdiction, is subject to judicial review if someone challenges it....this is hardly news.  However, as Mr. Workman notes, that is the responsibility of a Court, not of a County Commission.  

The Commissioners have "tabled" the measure for now and, in just under six months, we'll see if they wish to further pursue their ill-advised attempt to establish a preemptive veto power of County Initiatives.  Special interest groups have every opportunity to oppose an initiative as it's being circulated for signatures or, if it qualifies for the ballot, during the campaign for its passage. If an initiative passes which displeases a specific special interest group, the group has every opportunity to challenge the legality of the initiative.

Comment: I was predisposed to think this was going to be another of the puff filler pieces running on this site lately, but I actually enjoyed this pleasant little reflection. But then, I'm a sucker for sports analogies.

Calling balls and strikes is the most subjective thing umpires do, but it's the "safe/out" calls that matter most. Experienced umpires know that in the split-second when the play is happening, they can't possibly see everything. So they watch the base and listen for the sound of the ball hitting the glove. Instant replay shows that this approach works more often than not.

The analogy to the Church is that more than just one type of information is needed to make a just and compassionate pastoral decision. I think Pope Francis gets that. I'm not so sure about some other members of the hierarchy.

Comment: I'd like to comment but hardly know where to begin.  I've worked almost 40 years in the industry as a researcher for service companies.  This includes work with fracturing chemicals for a period.  I've blown up the photo as large as Google will let me, looking for pump jacks, on site compressors, or other evidence of producing wells.  (The entire block is the site, not just the building at the upper left.  I do find racked pipe toward the lower left side of the picture.  It is in single 30' lengths and is quite corroded -- possible evidence of use in a well with hydrogen sulfide presence.  But only possible.  That gas is  extremely corrosive to oil field pipe and deadly.   The long cream colored piping in the upper right hand side of the picture is insulated pipe, suggesting that the field is under some sort of steam flood and must lead directly to whatever well head(s).  Limonene is widely used in the industry as "grease cutting" solvent with a strong citrus smell.

Comment: More car travel does not mean more deaths unless one cannot change the rate of death per mile. A casual observation of the way local motorists drive will further show that our motorists don't obey any laws, so we have great potential to save lives. 

Want to stop drunk driving? Zero-tolerance traffic law enforcement does it quite nicely. At first, this will simply lead to citations of sober but scofflaw motorists. As they learn and clean up their acts, the drunks will begin to stand out like sore thumbs. It's all a signal to noise issue, as well as the fact that we are currently choosing to not enforce our traffic laws so no one is even looking for the signal.

Comment: I think I got it and please correct me if I'm wrong.  You're saying rather than getting on the freeway at an on ramp that is east of the Piikoi on ramp , people would go west to the Ward on ramp to travel east on the freeway?  If so, and unless they already are near the Ward on ramp, I really don't think people who regularly use the Piikoi on ramp would double back and go west to the Ward on ramp if they want to travel east.  Rather, I think most people would go to an on ramp east of the Piikoi on ramp (E.g. University, Humane Society and Kapiolani near Kaimuki High School).  By doing so, they would enter the freeway after the congestion.  The same goes for those wanting to get to Punahou from the Piikoi on ramp.  Rather than double back to the Ward on ramp, they would be better off going on King, Young or Wilder, to get to Punahou.  I just can't see people doubling back to the Ward on ramp where the congestion is the worst along that area if they want to go east and/or Punahou.

Comment: It is utterly inexplicable that the Legislature is rushing forward with a tax that the voters overwhelmingly defeated months ago. Oregon needs to make its tax system more progressive, not less, and this new tax is perhaps the most regressive there is, since there is no way to exempt essentials like food and medicine. Low and middle income Oregonians should not pay one cent more in price increases while millionaires pay almost the same income tax rate as someone making less than $20,000 per year.

And throwing in the towel on the corporate income tax makes no sense. Reform it, for heavens sake. Business would likely support reasonable reform.

Our lawmakers need to listen to the very reasonable proposal from the business community of a temporary tax increase to get past the current budget crisis, with future reform discussed when there time to find a solution that is fair to all.

Comment: It's great to see the county looking at options in this budget climate.  Clearly they see the importance of community standards, attracting and keeping good residents, and maintaining property values.

It would be heartening to see similar progress unfold in the City of Port Angeles.  I believe we are in a state of decline, but not past the point of no return.  It's time for city leaders to recognize that allowing people (addicts) to sleep in their vehicles on city streets, allowing excessive residents to occupy one (drug) house, tolerating junk cars, languishing abandoned homes, and similar is not in the interest of the taxpayer.  

Some difficult decisions need to be made, and if it results in a decline in some services (e.g. attrition of current staff, and bring some code compliance folks aboard) to get the city cleaned up then that is progress.  City leaders - please lean forward, you can make positive changes.

Comment: I looked a lot of the available data and models back in the 80's and as time has gone on and I have followed it the overarching lesson I have taken away is that it's happening faster and faster.  Faster than anyone at all predicted back then - even on the fast end of the predictions.  The second thing I took away was the severity has been greater and greater than the best models can predict.  No one that I am aware of has overshot on the severity side.  That wasn't because the models weren't good, they just weren't omniscient.  The growth of China and India, the amount of methane that would be released when the ice sheets melt, etc.  Hawai'i needs to take the current sea level rise and plan for double that, and move the projections up by 10 or 20 years - if history is any guide.

Comment: The TPP was negotiated in utter secrecy by government appointees and corporate lawyers.  Interested officials outside the negotiating process were either refused access to the text, or could view only under strict supervision.  At no time was the general public invited to participate or observe. Rather than a "trade" pact, the TPP appears to be an "investors" pact which fundamentally changes the relationships between government, the people, and transnational capital - favouring the latter. Analysis conducted for the Canadian government revealed that the TPP would result in a net economic gain of 0.127% (less than 5 billion dollars), and that only over the next 22 years (see Global Affairs Canada "Economic Impact of Canada's Potential Participation in the Trans-Pacific Partnership"). 

So the idea is to fundamentally alter the structure of our country, quite possibly in very negative damaging ways, so to grow our economy barely more than one-tenth of 1% over next two decades.

Comment: Too bad.  Must have been a good design to have lasted in excess of 150 years.  The reality is that the building has suffered neglect and generations of poor maintenance, or non-maintenance as is the case with so many of our heritage buildings. The detail demonstrates the most basic lack of attention, with the negative grade adjacent to the foundation, funnelling the rainwater and drip water down the foundation wall.  How inept was the groundskeeping around this structure. 

The Europeans maintain these buildings for a thousand years. They are constantly restoring and maintaining to original specifications. Comment: The PFD is not wealth distribution because it does not come from tax payers, which is why it boosts the economy. The money comes from the Alaska constitution granting the citizens of Alaska the mineral rights to state land. Back when oil was being pumped out like gang busters, someone had a brilliant idea of investing all the oil profit into the stock market as a huge principle, and then pay out the interest made from the principle to the Alaskan people, as opposed to simply cutting them a check for their share of the oil profit.
Long story short, the money IS ours, not the state's, because Alaskans (not Alaska) own the mineral rights that made the principle for the PFD. We are getting the interest from our share of the states minerals, that's all.

Comment: Horrible idea. 
Firstly the cameras have never been shown to be accurate, and certainly there's plenty of room for error in Alaska's inclement weather (when one cannot see the crosswalk under snow/ice, how does one avoid entering it?). 
Second the cameras cannot differentiate between registered owner and driver. My car is registered only to me, who is on the financing. If my wife, relative whos visiting, etc is driving and violates, but the citation is issued to the license plate, I am cited for a violation I did not commit. The burden then falls to me to prove I'm not guilty, which is a corruption to the core of the justice system.
Third there's a whole constitutional issue with facing my accuser. How does one question a camera in court? How will the system be represented and questioned for flaws?

These are just 3 legal issues, nevermind the moral and ethical implications of corporate profiteering, etc on this. It's a bad idea and it should never be seriously considered.

Comment: So you think Quintillion, a for-profit company, has hired Alcatel Lucent and is spending billions on the Arctic Fiber cable to bring internet to a few remote communities on Alaska's west and north coasts? Doubtful.

Arctic Fiber is a way to cut microseconds off of trading algorithms buy and sell times between Japan and European stock exchanges by using the most direct route possible by cutting across the Arctic Ocean. It's financed by banks and big financial trading firms, especially Cooper Investment Partners. Alaska happens to be on the way, and Quintillion in their wisdom have secured federal subsidies to run offshoots from the cable to connect these local communities... it is also good PR to do this, and the cable benefits by power injection at regular intervals as well. But the notion that Arctic Fiber is being installed solely for these communities is laughable.

So my fact-based comments seem asinine to you (meaning "stupid or foolish") -- how do you figure?

Comment: "If land holdings, prestige and titles are up for inheritance, so too are the ongoing legacies of age-old crimes." This apparently persuasive statement is, or rests on, a false analogy, and in any case it strikes me as being beside the point.  Even if Prince Harry were to give up all his titles, together with his prestige, profit, and worldly goods, I bet Ms. Balkissoon would still be "at" him. And even if he did not exist any more, I get the distinct impression that she would be off on a quest for some other living person to blame.  She reminds me of one of those unhappy figures in Dante's Inferno: she is deeply unsatisfied -- in her case, in the desire to assign blame. However, we simply cannot convincingly blame people who are now living for what their ancestors may have done. We no longer accept the "sins of the fathers" argument about "the on-going legacies of age-old crimes." Harry himself has done nothing to merit being put on trial in the media for crimes that are "age-old."

Comment: Of course. I too spent weekends at the pick-and-pull scavenging parts for my bimmer. Imagine what an ordinary person without the tools or skills would have paid for the same repairs. Then subtract the costs related to those engine, transmission, coolant, emissions controls and exhaust systems that an EV doesn't have. Is the number bigger or smaller? 

So what can go wrong? Pads & disks last much longer because of regenerative braking. The battery pack will lose very little capacity over 25 years. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gb_i4ihsJ1w) Time, rather than usage, seems to be the more significant factor. Electric motors are sealed units, are a proven technology in much harsher applications and extremely durable. The reduction gearbox is a sealed unit and much simpler than any automatic, CVT or manual transmission. I expect that the charger/inverter electronics are as durable as the ECU/EMU. Especially since they are not subject to the extreme heat and vibration of the IC engine.

Comment: If you unpack the tables, pre/post Brady there was almost a 1 for 1 transference from buying from licensed dealers to "street" sales, which, by definition, background checks cannot impact. The guns there are either stolen (with an average "time to crime" from commercial sale to discovery of a decade per ATF), or are purchased by persons who can pass BGC's who then break the law by knowingly providing them to persons who are barred from ownership. There's no evidence that a significant number of firearms are purchased (illegally, as prohibited persons are not allowed to try to acquire firearms) by prohibited persons directly from unknowing legal owners.

On a practical side, BGC's are unenforceable unless the physical actually witnessed by law enforcement. There is no way to prove "X" owned gun "A" which is later found in the possession of "Y", much less how it got into "Y's" hands, which possession by "Y" is either legal if they are non-prohibited, or already a Federal felony crime.

Comment: There is a line between known calculable risks, which are stated, and which a company undertakes, and false reportage.  I'm not saying the financial statements were false, but the 2016 statements report only .3% of a very large mortgage book in default.  So what happened to the mortgages that were written under false pretenses.   The problem with Home Capital isn't that their mortgage brokers wrote 'liar loans'.  The problem isn't that there is default risk or interest rate change risk in those mortgages.  The problem is that investors did not learn how many loans were taken under false pretences, and the damage to the mortgage book, if any.  Investors have to assess based on financial statements, and if those are false, then ... you can't really blame the investors.  BTW, we don't know just how far off those financial statements are.

Comment: People who say, "They should come here the right way," need to understand that our immigration policies favor college-educated, middle-class people who happen to be white. Comment: Fun fact: Oregon's speed limits apply to ideal conditions. Comment: I think there is a lot to consider in Massingale's words. I also think he pulled his punch when he spoke of the struggle within the church. He pointed to Trump's campaign as tapping into fear, racism (etc.) While that may well be true, I'd suggest we all play back the political ads we've been hearing during campaigns now for a long time. Trump certainly didn't invent the concept, nor was he the only one to use it. The real issue is the cause of these fears. In society, there's no shortage of sources, including politicians, the media, movies, books, etc.

Where Massingale pulled his punch on the church was that he didn't call out similar sources in the church. I might disagree mightily with a neocon, or ultra liberal in the church, but I very much want to be open to a dialog with them. Can the same be said with church bishops and popes, who literally and often use THEIR pens and pulpits to reach millions with highly judgmental thoughts?

Comment: Hey, L2G, thanks for the plug, but I do get the impression they are going beyond the usual drivel about "Skinner's Mudhole." 
 It's great that they went to the university's Special Collections Archive, one of the UO's excellent but little-known resources.  I'm especially impressed they are featuring  Wayne Morse, Bill Bowerman, and Oregon's great suffragist Abigail Scott Duniway. 
Duniway spent more than a little time in Eugene speaking on women's right to vote, and arguing with local editors.  She with famous for her strength, dignity, and literary and political skills rather than the flamboyant  tactics used by some suffragists elsewhere.  (Read "Yours For Liberty.")
Including Whalan, Pfieiffer and Kesey adds an interesting touch of diversity to represent the local scene.  Though  as Jaded notes,it's ironic we'll have to search CSPANN to find this  rather than having such quality  programming regularly  on our local media.

If you carry a pistol for bears check the ft. Lbs. of energy and compare with say a 30-30, or a 30-06.
Steve Herrero, Canadian bear attack researcher, looked into deployment of defenses, I think less than 50% were deployed, bears are very fast.

Comment: Amazon is the best .....

An interesting experience:
A couple of years ago decided to install a bow thruster in our largish steel trawler yacht. Visited the local marine supplier - the staff was not interessted in my need but tried to sell me what they had in stock - which was totally undersize and not suitable. They did not even bother to suggest ordering the unit for me, the price they quoted after much debate seemed high. Fed up I went home - on the Internet - and was able to find and order the thruster from stock, a distributor in the UK. A heavy box 150Lb +.... shipped air fright across the Atlantic - at a lower cost than I was quoted in Canada !

Love it !!

Comment: My grandfather had a hearing aid in the 1950s that consisted of a little volume-adjustable amplifier about the size of a transistor radio that he carried in his pocket. He received the sound with a little wired earphone.

Those wishing to go old school can do the same thing with free smartphone hearing aid apps that do essentially the same thing in a more high-tech way. The phone acts as the amplifier and brings you the sound via the phone's earbuds. My current favorite for the iPhone is Petralex. It runs you through a hearing test and sets itself accordingly. As with hearing aids, you can have different settings for different environments. I presume there are similar apps for Android.

It isn't fashionable with the cords hanging out of your ears and it drains the phone's battery faster, but in a pinch the hearing correction is near as good as with my $2,000 Costco hearing aids.

Comment: Now, a presidential candidate could lose despite winning 78%+ of the popular vote and 39 states.

With the current state-by-state winner-take-all system of awarding electoral votes (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), it could only take winning a bare plurality of popular votes in only the 11 most populous states, containing 56% of the population of the United States, for a candidate to win the Presidency with less than 22% of the nation's votes!

In 2000, 537 popular votes in Florida determined that the candidate who had 537,179 less national popular votes would win.

Less than 80,000 votes in 3 states determined the 2016 election, where there was a lead of over 2,8oo,ooo  popular votes nationwide.

Since World War II, a shift of a few thousand votes in 1, 2, or 3 states would have elected a 2nd-place candidate in 6 of the 18 presidential elections

Comment: Although these four groups are neighbors, their spoken languages were not mutually intelligible.

Eyak is a single language with only one living speaker.

The Tlingit language has four main dialects: Northern, Southern, Inland and Gulf Coast with variations in accent from each village.

The Haida people speak an isolate (unrelated to other) language, Haida, with three dialects: Skidegate and Masset in British Columbia, Canada and the Kaigani dialect of Alaska.

The Tsimshian people speak another isolate language, Sm’algyax, which has four main dialects: Coast Tsimshian, Southern Tsimshian, Nisga’a, and Gitksan.

To keep any language alive is to help all mankind to understand each other better in this world!

Comment: KINDNESS OVER ALL
Keep us, O God, from all pettiness. Let us be large in thought, in word, in deed. let us be done with fault-finding and leave off all self-seeking. May we put away all pretense and meet each other face to face, without self pity and without prejudice. may we never be hasty in judgment, and always be generous. let us always take time for all things, and make us to grow calm, serene and gentle. Teach us to put into action our better impulses, to be straightforward and unafraid. Grant that we may realize that it is the little things of life that create differences, that in the big things of life, we are as one. And, O Lord God, let us not forget to be kind!
-Mary Stewart,  UK author of The Crystal Cave and many other romance/suspense novels -wrote her first poem at age 4.She said, "Don't forget what a dreadful life these medieval women led shut up in those ghostly castles, while the men were away having fun. Nothing to do but your embroidery and pay ball in the garden"

Comment: I'm sure you were raised to listen to and respect authority.  Most Americans were.   So much so that psychologist Stanley Milgram devised the "Milgrim experiment."   I cannot summarize it sufficiently here, but Milgram was attempting to study the effect of authority figures on ordinary people from all walks of life.   This was in the 60s when the Eichmann trial was international news, and the question of how Nazi Germany could have occurred was questioned by most people in the world.  

Milgram didn't express his conclusions in the exact way I do, but essentially the Milgram experiment proved that 2 out of every 3 people will kill someone they know nothing about just because another person they know nothing about told them to, if the third party appeared to authoritative, i.e., wore a white coat, made notes and directed the experiment. 

I think that experiment is one of the most compelling ever.

Comment: Your logic is flawed if you think that the COA ruling is comparing dogs to trained officers. The subjectivity of detecting alcohol is weighed by an officer who can articulate his findings in order to heighten an investigation from reasonably suspecting that alcohol is present, to finding probable cause that alcohol use is prohibiting a driver from operating a vehicle in a an unaltered state. All that the ruling says, at it's core, is that a dog, who can detect multiple types of illegal substances, can only 'tell' his handler that at least one of those substances is present. The dog's ability to communicate with his handler is dampened simply because the dog is just that, a dog. If narcotics dogs, in the future, can accurately demonstrate a different 'tell' for each different and distinct substance, then this ruling would have no application to those scenario. The COA was spot on here, especially in light of Rodriguez V U.S (2015) as the courts are, rightly, limiting unchecked K9 power

1. LNG; late to the game and next there is a saturated market with falling prices, served by those who are well established and are already delivering.

Comment: I think many of the bloggers here misunderstand this particularly tax change.
Only a small percentage of doctors are effected. Really only specialists that work in academic / university hospital settings. These are the most highly trained doctors. They perform research and provide medical education. And fund both of those in part out of their own practice earnings. Academic  / university doctors already make up to half what community single physician doctors make of the same specialty. The tax change does not effect the higher earning single incorporated physician. They will still get the small business tax rate. It is only academic physicians in large group practices that lose the small business tax rate. Problem is that those are the most mobile of physicians, recruited regularly by large US academic medicine centres. Also the most difficult to replace because training for academic specialists is longer, usually 7 years or more.

Comment: Hello Evan. Hope all's well. I believe God to be fully, 100% responsible for the creation of the universe and of life - I don't believe that all matter and energy just came from nothing by accident and that life in it's tremendous complexity just happened by random accident. Now as to the mechanics of how it was done, there is quite of range of thought within even the Christian community, from an absolute literal six 24-hour-day creation with a young earth, to a very old earth with guided evolution. A long-time pastor and friend teaches an old-earth timeline that can be supported from the Bible, but not all Christians would agree with him (but many would). I definitely don't believe in classic atheistic Darwinian evolution, and I don't believe the fossil record, when looked at carefully, actually supports it - Darwin was working with much less data than we have now. I do believe in micro-evolution, versus macro-evolution - there's lots of information available online about that.

Comment: Another extremely humorous line for anyone with any real-world experience in the libertarian movement: "Buchanan's career as the intellectual godfather of libertarianism..." Though I went into medicine, not academics, I've been part of the libertarian movement for over 40 years. I was one of the first interns at the Cato Institute. I'm on a first name basis with a many libertarian academics. I have a library of over 100 textbooks in history, economics, philosophy, & political theory with a libertarian thrust. And though I *own* one or two books by Buchanan, I've never actually READ any books by Buchanan. I'm familiar with Public Choice theory because it's a major field of economics, NOT because Buchanan is some sort of intellectual godfather of the movement. That's laughably absurd. See also this point made by law professor David Bernstein: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2017/07/17/how-influential-was-james-buchanan-among-libertarians/?utm_term=.40295e46dd56

Comment: Historically, Oregon legislators and State officials have had as much interest in quality higher education as they have had in Saturn. Their interest has been in how to get degrees to as many students as possible in as short a time as possible for as little expense as possible. Their euphemism for degrading education is "removing obstacles to graduation." I wouldn't count on them for holding anyone accountable for anything but spending less.

The UO, like many universities, has to cater to a customer base that includes out of state and international students in order for it to stay in business. How far this catering goes depends on "enrollment management" needs. EM is quite a complicated part of the forecasting business for hitting targets. These customers require marketing strategies and retention efforts against competition from other U's.

Given the pressures and limits, faculty at the UO generally do a courageous and effective job of preserving educational quality.

Comment: Again, Elagabalus, I don't think the issue is that simple. Indeed, from your and my perspective, a reasonable business proprietor living in a morally diverse society would adopt tolerance among those with different moral values as a positive virtue to be practiced in religiously diverse societies. But what are the limits? That is the problem! How do we accommodate people of honest, but scrupulous conscience? 

Religious freedom and laws do conflict. True respect for freedom on conscience requires us to think out of our moral boxes. More often than not, I am inclined to direct my moral anger at religious leaders. So here, I have empathy for the poor baker, but none for the religious leaders of his faith, which I assume to be Christian, who irrationally continue to support gay discrimination on faulty biblical exegesis.

So you and your spouse come home and both plug in your 32 amp chargers to recharge the 100km you each drove that day. Then you want to cook dinner while your kids use the computers, watch TV, etc. Not to mention your HVAC (furnace, AC, HRV, etc) equipment loads. OOPS, not enough power.

You got between $4000-$10000 laying around to upgrade your home electrical service? You will need it.

Comment: The insurable interest would not be excluded by legal activity, only illegal activity.  So, if you rented out your house or condo in an area that is zoned residential or apartment to tourists on a regular basis, no insurance coverage for you.  If it is zoned for resort, then a condo in Waikiki would be allowed to get insurance coverage.  A very simple fix that has been staring everyone in the face for years.  

This means the City does not have to go around chasing down violators as well who put up apartments in those areas zoned for single family residences.  With no insurable interest, illegal apartment renters would soon find out that they cannot get renters' insurance coverage as well.  Leaving them exposed for personal liability and total loss in case of a fire.

This simple change solves a myriad of problems, from affordable housing with thousands of units available for local residents and families, to eliminating illegal rentals to tourists and local communities. Not a rookie.

Comment: Murkowski's complaint about ANWR becoming a monument has little to no connection with the residents of the islands wanting a sanctuary around their homes and requesting one. An ANWR monument would not violate ANILCA because ANILCA specifically exempted areas set aside prior to 1980. ANWR was set aside in 1960. Further, the 'no more clause' in ANILCA would not survive close examination by the courts, who have held since 1920 that large monuments are permitted, and that the size of the monument is the presidents call. Monuments in ANWR and Bristol Bay will be upheld, under Supreme Court precedent, and the fact AK has no standing to challenge any monuments in its borders , under Alaska vs Carter (1980). It is the courts, not Congress, that determine the legality of actions by the presidents, in the case of monuments, the courts have upheld every monument ever challenged, including all 17 of Carters. Likewise any monuments Obama creates will be upheld.

Comment: Two other things to remember about the Juneau "access" road. 

1.  Real cost:  It's not a $574 million "access" road as both advocates and some opponents say. It's more like a $1 billion "access" road.

The $574 million hasn't been updated in a couple years. Each time it has been updated, the costs have gone up $100 million or more.  As a former DOT official famously and truthfully said,  "We won't know the real total cost until we issue a contract," or something to that effect. 

2.  Impact on other regions:  Whether it's a $1 billion "access" road or a mere $574 million "access" road, there will be severe impacts on other parts of Southeast Alaska as well as Anchorage, MatSu, Fairbanks and the rest of the state. 

Advocates of the "access" road like to say it's 90% federal money and only 10% state match. What they conveniently forget to say is that's $480 million (or more) and 10% match that won't be available for critically needed projects elsewhere in Alaska.

Comment: Shurtz' status as a public employee is irrelevant. Employers, whether private or public, may implement policy or code of conduct for employees. Comment: "He [Franklin] was writing about a tax dispute between the Pennsylvania General Assembly and the family of the Penns, the proprietary family of the Pennsylvania colony who ruled it from afar. And the legislature was trying to tax the Penn family lands to pay for frontier defense during the French and Indian War. And the Penn family kept instructing the governor to veto. Franklin felt that this was a great affront to the ability of the legislature to govern. And so he actually meant purchase a little temporary safety very literally. The Penn family was trying to give a lump sum of money in exchange for the General Assembly's acknowledging that it did not have the authority to tax it."

"So far from being a pro-privacy quotation, if anything, it's a pro-taxation and pro-defense spending quotation.
It means, in context, not quite the opposite of what it's almost always quoted as saying but much closer to the opposite than to the thing that people think it means."
